review_title: Great Experience in First Few Months
pros:
Of the dozens of people I interact with, not a single one has an ego. Everyone is passionate about what we work on and it is an absolute pleasure and privilege to work with them. I started this summer and have truly not had a single negative experience. I'm still finding my way, but my co-workers are extremely intelligent and driven individuals. I can't speak to other divisions, but the Watson squads are above and beyond.

To sum up the general vibe, I would say just about everyone, including senior management, are genuine and honest people motivated by common sense.
cons:
There's really nothing to complain about in the 5 months I've worked here. But to explain my 4-star ratings:

Compensation and Benefits: The salary is nothing to scoff at, but it is slightly lower than what my friends are making at big-name companies like Microsoft, Amazon, Disney, and Salesforce once adjusted for cost-of-living. Most of my other job offers were a bit higher and came with stock options. 

Work/Life Balance: It is very good in general, and I don't know how it is when people work in the office, but while WFH, there are a decent number of people who work outside of the 9-5 range. Given how much it seems my co-workers enjoy what they do, some of them have the live-to-work mentality and often work more than 8 hours a day. That being said, it is definitely not expected for one to work more than 8 hours a day.

review_title: GBS North America technical roles are below industry standard
pros: The benefits are about the same as other large companies. Internal tools are acceptable. Lots of emphasis on training with free online courses.
cons: IBM is a big company and experiences are different in each country, as well as in the different divisions within IBM and the roles that are done. I work in GBS, North America, and the pay is far below industry standard for equivalent skills. 50 hour work weeks are expected, and the pay doesn't reflect that. There are no significant raises, no promotions, and no awards. Travel is expected and, in many cases, is in addition to the 50 hours of customer billable time. There continues to be a focus to move all US technical jobs overseas or into low-cost (low paying) IBM centers, so all technical jobs are assumed to be expendable at any time. "Resource Actions" happen at least once a year, where upper level management chooses a skill and randomly fires hundreds, if not thousands, of employees - and it's not based on performance (and generally affects the older, higher-paid employees). Upper level management does an awful lot of patting themselves on the back with one hand for their great decisions, while never actually growing the company: very few executives are ever fired for incompetence - and they never admit that they might be the problem: their explanation is that the problem is with the line employees for not billing enough hours. First line managers can not "manage" employees because they have their own non-employee-management goals that they are paid/rewarded for (like finding new business or performing technical jobs), as opposed to paying them for successfully helping their team.

review_title: IBM handles COVId-19 in a caring manner
pros:
COVID-19 challenged everyone, and IBM.
I really appreciate the way IBM is handling COVID-19.
They approach it very professionally and in a manner that helps people.
These include:
- Additional paid leave to take care of you or your people,
- Countless seminars on COVID, safety and vaccinations
- Educational material on protecting yourself, your family, your client and IBM
- Creating guidelines for employees and managers on what to do when COVID strikes someone, keeping personal identity secret.
Just appreciate all that I am seeing.
cons: Keep looking for ways to stay competitive.

review_title: Ideal place to start your career. Not ideal for career growth.
pros:
- Diverse work environment. Not discrimination when it comes to age, religion or gender. 
- The majority of my former colleagues were approachable, open-minded and helpful.
- My managers were understanding when it comes to personal matters. I never felt scared or nervous to explain my side.
- Lots of free learning materials and extra curricular activities.
-Never late when it comes to payout of salaries and bonuses. HR responds to queries immediately.
-Good work and life balance. You have time to work on a freelance job or hobby.
cons:
- Lower salary compared to other companies.
- Slow career growth. Promotion comes rare even if you do a great job for years, with great client feedback. Worse, sometimes the questionable people get promoted to a higher band.
- Bureaucracy leads to slow dissemination of information and decision making.
- The expertise of some SME's are disappointing.

job_title: Client Success Manager, Project Executive in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Coworkers and first level and mid-level managers were some of the best and brightest I've worked with. Good teamwork. 

Base salary was very good.

Flexible schedules and work from home are commonplace.
cons:
A couple times each year there will be a resource action with layoffs ranging from less than a hundred to multiple thousands. Morale suffers. 

Most of my coworkers joined IBM through an acquisition. In other words, most did not choose IBM and apply for an opening there. 

IBM delays matching your 401(k) contributions until Dec. 15, at which time IBM makes a once-a-year contribution for the previous twelve months of accrued match. If you leave IBM (or IBM lays you off) before the company match contribution is made, too bad; you receive $zero match for the entire year; no prorated match.

There are so many silos and divisions that there are duplicate processes. 

IBM uses Notes for email and calendar.
